items.title: Food allergies can be triggered in infancy, a new review says. Here's how
items.summary_auto: A new review of studies gives families and doctors a better understanding of what drives food allergies in babies and children.

items.title: Trump threats on Gordie Howe bridge opening 'just insane,' Windsor mayor says
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's threat to stall the opening of the new Canada- U.S. border crossing is "just insane," Windsor Mayor Drew Dilkens said Monday night.

items.title: Trump threatens to block opening of new bridge between Windsor and Detroit
Liberal MP Bruce Fanjoy criticizes government's latest return-to-office order
items.summary_auto: Bruce Fanjoy, the Liberal MP for Carleton, has broken ranks with his party to criticize the federal  government's latest return-to-office (RTO) mandate.

items.title: Guthrie family at 'hour of desperation' in search for their missing mother
items.summary_auto: Savannah Guthrie's family is "at an hour of desperation" in the search for her missing mother, the Today show co-host said in a video released Monday ahead of a looming ransom deadline apparently set by Nancy Guthrie's abductors.

items.title: Canada beats Czechia, but captain Poulin exits game with apparent injury
items.summary_auto: Canadian captain Marie-Philip Poulin left the first period of an Olympic women's hockey game against Czechia with an apparent knee injury and did not return for the second.

items.title: Catherine O'Hara died of blood clot in lung, says L.A. Medical Examiner's Office
items.summary_auto: Actor Catherine O'Hara died of a blood clot in her lung, according to the Los Angeles Medical Examiner's Office.

items.title: Fact check: Are Russia and Belarus in the Olympics?
items.summary_auto: Twenty athletes with Russian and Belarusian passports are competing in the Winter Olympics, but they’re not representing a country. Here are the facts about 'Individual Neutral Athletes.'

items.title: Conservatives, Liberals in behind-the-scenes negotiations as PM downplays election talk
items.summary_auto: Liberals and Conservatives are working out a path that could keep the government in power, sources tell CBC News, while Prime Minister Mark Carney continues to downplay the likelihood of a spring election.

items.title: 'Operational pressure' sparks Via Rail cancellations in Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal
items.summary_auto: Via Rail says recent train cancellations within its Toronto-Ottawa-Montreal corridor are being made in response to "heightened operational pressure."

items.title: B.C. Greens pull out of cooperation agreement with B.C. NDP
items.summary_auto: The Greens, which have two seats in B.C.’s legislature, will not sign a new co-operation agreement with the NDP government, saying the party has stalled or sidelined too many of the measures it agreed to.

items.title: Ancient people had nautical tech, know-how to cross hazardous Arctic channel
items.summary_auto: Archeologists have found the remains of a cluster of tents with hearths on a remote High Arctic island that date back more than 4,000 years. They offer surprising new insights about the first people who lived near what is now the Canada-Greenland border.

items.title: Manitoba announces school funding hike, but divisions say they're still facing significant financial pressure
items.summary_auto: Manitoba schools are getting an overall 3.5 per cent raise in funding from the province in the coming school year, the education minister announced Monday.

items.title: NBA star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander now partly owns Hamilton's TD Coliseum
items.summary_auto: There are also plans for community programming and events at the venue, in collaboration with Gilgeous- Alexander's charitable organization, says the Oak View Group.

items.title: Trial begins for Sask. group home worker charged with assaulting residents
items.summary_auto: Jaclyn Elias, 38, was fired from the Prairie Branches group home after the allegations arose two years ago in the small community of Wilkie, Sask.

items.title: Lindsey Vonn says she'll need multiple surgeries to repair broken leg after Olympic crash
items.summary_auto: Lindsey Vonn says she "sustained a complex tibia fracture that is currently stable but will require multiple surgeries to fix properly" after her devastating crash in the Olympic downhill.

items.title: Ghislaine Maxwell takes the Fifth in U.S. House committee appearance from prison
items.summary_auto: Lawmakers tried on Monday to interview Ghislaine Maxwell but the former girlfriend and confidante of Jeffrey Epstein invoked her Fifth Amendment rights to avoid answering questions that would be self-incriminating.

items.title: Sask. man makes public plea for help finding long-lost guitar strap signed by Joan Baez
items.summary_auto: Seeking to recover an item with deep sentimental value, a man recently posted on Reddit about a long-lost guitar strap. He had borrowed the strap from his father over 15 years ago, and lost it. Now, he's hoping it will make its way back home.

items.title: With a roster speckled red and white, Italy's victory in women's hockey is Canada's too
items.summary_auto: As the final anxious seconds ticked away in Italy's 3-2 win over Japan on Monday, Daniele Sauvageau, the team’s Canadian general manager, looked at 35-year-old Laura Fortino, a gold-medal winner with Canada in 2014 who now wears Italian blue, both with tears in their eyes.

items.title: Animal welfare group overseeing medical research in London, Ont. defends dog testing
items.summary_auto: Western University's Animal Care Committee cleared researcher Frank Prato's controversial use of dogs in medical research but a philosophy professor who specializes in ethics of animal treatment says he still has questions about how the tests were carried out.

items.title: Canadian speed skater Béatrice Lamarche 5th in women's 1,000 metres of her Olympic debut
items.summary_auto: A trio of Canadian women made their Olympic speed skating debuts on Monday in the 1,000 metres, with Béatrice Lamarche leading the way in fifth.

items.title: 'They were brothers': Players, families remember 3 who died in Alberta highway crash
items.summary_auto: Family, teammates and friends spoke about JJ Wright and Cameron Casorso, both from Kamloops, B.C., and Caden Fine from Alabama ahead of a memorial benefit game in their honour Sunday.

items.title: Federal government loans $1.01B to Canada Post as postal service continues to struggle
items.summary_auto: The federal government is making more than $1 billion available to Canada Post in the form of a repayable loan to help the beleaguered Crown corporation remain solvent and keep its services running.

items.title: Ukrainian skeleton racer at Olympics says his helmet tribute to fallen athletes won't be allowed by IOC
items.summary_auto: Vladyslav Heraskevych showed up for the Milan Cortina Olympics with a new helmet, one featuring the images of some fellow Ukrainian athletes killed in Russian attacks. And Heraskevych wanted to offer a tribute. The International Olympic Committee, he said, won't let it happen.

items.title: Air Canada, WestJet winding down flights to Cuba as Havana airport warns it will run out of jet fuel
items.summary_auto: Air Canada and WestJet both said they would begin suspending service to Cuba effective Monday as the Caribbean island's major airport warns it will run out of jet fuel.

items.title: Decoding the nods to Latino culture in Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl performance
First bowling alley in Somalia welcomes middle class and diaspora returnees
items.summary_auto: The Feynuus Bowling Center in Mogadishu is the latest sign of revival in the once-thriving Indian Ocean port shaped by 35 years of civil war and militant bombings.

items.title: Buckingham Palace prepared to 'support' any police investigation into Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor
items.summary_auto: Buckingham Palace said on Monday it is ready to support any police investigation into King Charles's younger brother after emails suggested Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor might have shared confidential British trade documents with Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: At least 53 killed after migrant boat sinks off Libyan coast
items.summary_auto: Two babies are among at least 53 people dead or missing after an inflatable migrant boat sank off Libya, the UN migration agency said on Monday, the latest tragedy on a dangerous route for those seeking a better life in Europe.

items.title: Grief grows as bodies of kidnapped workers of Canadian mining company identified in Mexico
items.summary_auto: Jaime Castañeda was in the coastal Mexican city of Mazatlán on Sunday to identify the body of his 43-year-old brother. José Manuel Castañeda Hernández was working for Vancouver-based mining company Vizsla Silver Corp. when he was kidnapped last month, along with nine other employees.

items.title: U of A staff, students speak out against move to axe EDI from hiring policy
items.summary_auto: The University of Alberta is proposing to eliminate Equity, Diversity and Inclusion (EDI) from its hiring policy, a year after the school initially said it was moving away from the term.

items.title: To attract more doctors, Grand Forks commits to covering medical clinic costs
items.summary_auto: The City of Grand Forks in the B.C. Interior has teamed up with a local doctor to help cover the costs of running a medical clinic. It's being done in an effort to attract more local physicians, an effort the city says is already working.

items.title: N.S. entrepreneur developing mushroom roots as sustainable, high-protein food product
items.summary_auto: Researchers at Acadia University, along with startup Mycaro, have produced mycelium that is about 40 per cent protein. They use local agricultural processing waste as a food source for the mushroom roots.

items.title: A year after a major comic book distributor went bankrupt, N.L. shops are still reeling
items.summary_auto: Comic book shops and a publisher in St. John's are still grappling with the repercussions more than a year after a major distributor declared bankruptcy.

items.title: Cubans wonder if they could be next after Venezuela as rumours swirl about U.S. talks
items.summary_auto: There are unconfirmed reports that secret talks have begun between the CIA and Alejandro Castro Espín, the son of Raúl Castro. U.S. President Trump has said talks are on, and Cuban President Miguel Díaz-Canel has said the Communist Party is open to talking about "substantive" matters, but it's still not clear if that includes an end to one-party rule.
